contentrichtext.text: {{About|the former administrative district of Rügen|the island|Rügen}} {{Infobox District DE | name=Rügen | state=Mecklenburg-Vorpommern | capital=[[Bergen auf Rügen|Bergen]] | area=973.92 | Kreisschlüssel = |dissolved = 2011 | population=67526 | population_as_of=2010 | density= | carsign=RÜG | url= [http://www.kreis-rueg.de kreis-rueg.de] | map=mecklenburg_wp_rueg.png }} '''Rügen''' was a ''Kreis'' (district) in the northeastern part of [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]], [[Germany]]. The district of Rügen was created in 1806 by the Swedish administration of [[Swedish Pomerania]]. At first it was named ''Amt Bergen'', in 1810 it was renamed to ''Kreis Bergen''. On 4 September 2011, Rügen was merged to [[Vorpommern-Rügen]]. The district was bordered entirely by the Baltic Sea. The nearest districts were [[Nordvorpommern]] and the district-free city [[Stralsund]]. The district covered the islands [[Rügen]] and [[Hiddensee]], and several small islands like [[Ummanz]] and [[Vilm]]. It was thus the only district of Germany which consists solely of islands. ==Coat of arms== {| |- valign=top ||[[Image:Wappen Landkreis Ruegen.png|100px|Coat of arms]] ||The coat of arms derives from the coat of arms of the Principality of Rügen of the 13th century, with the only addition of a crown.
